name: Dr. Phalgun Lolur
title: Global Scientific Quantum Development Lead
bio: Phalgun Lolur is the Global Scientific Quantum Development Lead at Capgemini Quantum Lab, where he drives the intersection of quantum chemistry, materials science, data-driven methods, and quantum computing. With over 15 years of experience, he has been endorsed by the Royal Society for his expertise in theoretical and computational chemistry, quantum chemistry and computing. Dr. Lolur leads multidisciplinary teams to create innovative solutions in various sectors, focusing on integrating quantum computing with classical methodologies to form multi-scale modelling frameworks. His passion lies in developing practical quantum computing applications that tackle challenging problems in chemistry and materials science, positioning him as a leader in leveraging quantum technologies for materials innovation and scientific advancement.
talkTitle: Quantum Leap: Navigating Career Possibilities in Quantum Technologies
talkAbstract: Quantum technologies are on the brink of revolutionizing industries, from computing and cryptography to healthcare and energy, promising transformational advancements that will redefine our understanding of what's possible in the modern world. In this talk, Dr Phalgun Lolur, who serves as the Global Scientific Quantum Development Lead at Capgemini will explore the exciting realm of quantum technologies through his journey in research across academia, national labs and industry. Attendees will discover diverse career pathways for students and learn how to equip themselves with the skills and resources needed to thrive in this transformative field.

name: Dr. Gushu Li
title: Assistant Professor of Engineering and Applied Science
bio:
Dr. Gushu Li is an Assistant Professor in the Department of Computer and
  Information Science at the University of Pennsylvania (with a secondary
  appointment in Electrical and Systems Engineering) where he leads the Penn
   Quantum System Lab since January 2023, following his Ph.D. from the
  University of California, Santa Barbara under the advisement of Prof. Yuan
   Xie and Prof. Yufei Ding. His research spans the full stack of quantum
  computing systems including quantum compiler design, quantum programming
  languages, quantum algorithm optimization, quantum computer architecture,
  and quantum electronic design automation, with his work achieving
  exceptional real-world impact through widespread industry adoption—most
  notably his SABRE (SWAP-based BidiREctional heuristic search) qubit
  mapping algorithm published at ASPLOS'19, which has been selected as the
  default mapping algorithm in IBM's Qiskit and adopted by Oak Ridge
  National Lab's XACC/QCOR compiler, and his Paulihedral compilation
  framework from ASPLOS'22, a generalized block-wise compiler optimization
  framework for quantum simulation kernels that employs a novel Pauli
  intermediate representation to maintain high-level semantics and enable
  large-scale optimizations, which has been integrated into IBM's Qiskit,
  Amazon's Braket, Quantinuum's TKET, and Oak Ridge National Lab's qcor. His
   pioneering contributions have earned him prestigious recognition
  including the 2024 NSF Faculty Early CAREER Award, the 2024 Intel Rising
  Star Faculty Award, the 2024 NVIDIA Academic Grant Program Award, the ACM
  SIGPLAN Distinguished Paper Award at OOPSLA 2020 (for his projection-based
   assertion technique for quantum program debugging, also adopted by
  Quantinuum's TKET compiler), and the 2021 NSF QISE-NET Triplet Fellowship
  Award, with his 42 research works accumulating 1,296 citations and
  establishing him as a leading figure in bridging the gap between
  theoretical quantum computing and practical, scalable quantum software
  systems for NISQ-era devices.
talkTitle: The Software Bridge: How Quantum Compilers Translate Algorithms into Reality
talkAbstract: Quantum computers promise to solve certain problems far faster than classical computers—but programming them is far from straightforward. Between high-level algorithms and fragile quantum hardware lies a crucial layer of software: the quantum compiler. This talk introduces the basic ideas behind quantum compilation and explains how compilers translate human-written quantum programs into the physical instructions that hardware can execute. We will walk through the main steps of the compilation process, explore how optimizations improve performance and reduce errors, and discuss ongoing challenges such as noise, limited connectivity, and hardware diversity. No prior background in quantum computing is required—just curiosity about how software makes quantum computing possible.
